comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: adb.anu.edu.au/biography/de-chair-sir-dudley-rawson-strat... - de Chair's ADB entry, plus a pic Muir tentatively identified via this pic www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8283744212/ There might be a couple of other Dorman Long & Co employees here...eg. Alfred Martin, assistant to Lawrence Ennis, might be one of the gents standing on the lhs...this 1932 SMH pic of the Dorman Long & Co Harbour Bridge staff suggests a few other 'possibles' trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1157143 ; not sure whether there are any of the NSW PWD Harbour Bridge staff 'regulars' present...this PHM version of the 1932 SMH pic includes a good few of them www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/8282694749/ The chap standing 2nd lhs back row looks a little bit like Bill Ratcliffe, who was NSW Secretary for Works briefly in 1927...here's his NSW Parliament 'former members' entry - www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/1fb6e... ; If the occasion was important enough to warrant the attendance of the NSW Governor, then you'd think a NSW Government minister or two might also have been there... Note the inscription carved on the block...the words '...stone was...' are visible.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This photo has turned into a bit of a puzzle! Here's a SMH pictorial item on the laying of the Harbour Bridge foundation stone on 26/3/1925. It includes a pic of the NSW Governor Sir Dudley de Chair and other VIPs on the dais and also a pic of the foundation stone trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16194943 There are numerous pics of this 1925 ceremony in the various collections, eg. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=44265 ; investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... Now, hidden away in the maze that is NSW Transport RMS (is that still their name this week?) there's a further pic which also appears to have been taken on the same occasion as this SLNSW pic...this NSW Transport RMS pic is particularly significant because it shows the inscription on the block...I'm trying to discover how to link to this pic...the link dies once the session times out...this (maybe!) gets you to the NSW Transport RMS photo library front door www.rtaphotolibrary.com.au ...then either search for this pic 19250326HB001.jpg or key in 'de chair' A quick trawl thru the digitised newspapers reveals that this block is a second commemorative stone which was temporarily parked on a pedestal on the Harbour Bridge site in 1925 and then in 1927 was set in place on one of the southern pylons at Dawes Point...as this this 1927 SMH news item explains - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16371496 ; accompanying pic - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16371276 Here's the stone as it appears in situ www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=... Note that the caption accompanying the NSW Transport RMS pic suggests it was taken on 26/3/1925, which is the date of the inscription on the block...but if we look at the numerous pics of the proceedings at the laying of the Harbour Bridge foundation stone on 26/3/1925, we can see that de Chair was dressed in his naval uniform that day, not in a suit and winter overcoat and hat as we see in this SLNSW pic...so I'd say we're looking at a different day altogether...and probably sometime in winter Now here's the puzzle. Initially I thought that this SLNSW pic might have been taken at the stone setting ceremony at the southern pylon on 21/6/1927....however, over at SRNSW they have a couple of pics of that ceremony...and as is evident, they don't match up with this pic! investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... As thing stand, my guess is that in this SLNSW pic we see the stone either on its temporary pedestal...or maybe in the process of being moved into position at the southern pylon...on the day of the 1927 ceremony...the fact that de Chair is holding a trowel tends to suggest that some kind of official stone setting was in train...this one might require a visit to a library...work in progress

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's the Lang ministry at the time of the 1927 stone setting ceremony - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1213589 ; You can read about them on the former member pages here... www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/web/common.nsf/key/Archive... ; some additional mug-shots appear here nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16390278 ; The only 'possibles' from this lot that I can tentatively identify are Public Works and Railways Secretary Bill Ratcliffe (possibly the gent to the left of de Chair) www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/1fb6e... and Labour and Industry Secretary R.W. Cruickshank (possibly the chap behind Alfred Martin) www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/1fb6e...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6246974 another pic which I suspect involves this same ? 1927 ceremony...all very confusing!
